summary: Daniel A. Parsons appears to be an individual who compiled notes and memos, possibly related to intelligence or investigative work. His notes, dated May 12, 1978, detail the career and assignments of an Air Force officer and reference individuals and operations, potentially linking to the Penkovsky case. Another memo from the same date contains notes on Parsons' career, including his Air Force cover, relationships with organizations like USIA and CIA, and individuals connected to him, along with information about indexing and file management. He is also mentioned in a document receipt dated June 5, 1978, which includes sanitized notes on individuals like William Alexander Morgan and George de Mohrenschildt, suggesting Parsons may have been involved in handling or reviewing sensitive information related to these figures.
significance: Daniel A. Parsons' significance in the JFK assassination context is related to his potential involvement in intelligence activities and his access to or compilation of notes on individuals connected to the assassination, such as George de Mohrenschildt and David Ferrie. His notes and connections to organizations like the CIA and USIA suggest he may have been involved in gathering or managing information relevant to the investigation, though the exact nature and extent of his involvement remain unclear based on the provided documents.
